definition.content:
This dashboard provides a comprehensive view into the health and behavior of your observability pipelines. It helps with analyzing:

**Pipeline Inventory, Rollouts & Trends:** Understand which pipelines are running, how recently they were deployed, which OP worker versions are serving traffic, and how request volume and errors are changing over time.

**Resource Usage & Capacity:** Monitor memory consumption, CPU allocation, and host-level CPU usage to assess whether pipelines are appropriately resourced or approaching saturation.

**Traffic Flow & Throughput:** Track events and bytes flowing through pipelines and components to identify changes in load, bottlenecks, or unexpected reductions in throughput.

**Component Health, Backpressure & Data Reduction:** Examine component utilization, detect backpressure, and understand both intentional and unintentional event drops caused by filtering, sampling, quotas, or downstream constraints.

**Destination Reliability & Operational Debugging:** Monitor request success and error rates to downstream destinations and use OP worker logs to investigate failures, validate fixes, and troubleshoot issues in real time.

Useful for seeing the most recently deployed pipelines (where issues will most likely occur as older pipelines likely continue to behave as they have been in a majority of cases). Also overview of what versions of OP are running.

definition.title: Pipelines with highest events per component

definition.content: Pipelines with the highest events per component (ranked by total in pipelines, then split by component). Can also offer insight into the complexity of a pipeline (number of components).

When rolling out new versions of the worker, it can be helpful to see to switch over and requests going to the new version vs old version when you have multiple workers. This can be helpful if you are performing a rollout or canary to test new versions as they get promoted through lower-tier(s) and production environments.

definition.title: OP Worker requests per pipeline by Worker Version
% Change week over week in requests by pipeline and component type
% Change week over week in request errors by pipeline and component type

definition.content: OP Worker CPU usage per OPW host via process monitoring, normalized to show usage based on total cores available. Look for any pipelines which are trending towards 100% or pegged. This relies on [process monitoring](https://docs.datadoghq.com/integrations/process/), be sure to enable it to gain these insights. Unfortunately this telemetry type is unable to use template variables.
High memory or hosts which are low on free memory, can be indicators to scale your OP workers.

All components in Observability Pipelines workers have buffers by default, which help ease the flow of events through your pipeline.

Destinations can be configured with a either an in-memory or disk buffer. These buffers can help mitigate backpressure in the event of a destination becoming unavailable, and improve pipeline durability.

Read more about [buffers in Observability Pipelines here](https://docs.datadoghq.com/observability_pipelines/scaling_and_performance/handling_load_and_backpressure/#component-buffers)
Look for irregularities (spikes, dips) in events received, correlate with other data to understand spikes elsewhere (such as CPU usage).

Events in and events out **per component**; Use in conjunction with `pipeline_id` template variable to isolate this to a single pipeline, then further reduce to a single component by `component_id` to get a clear cut understanding if a single pipeline component is significantly sending or reducing events more than expected.

definition.title: Events in/out per pipeline per component

definition.content: Look for irregularities (spikes, dips) in events send, correlate with other data to understand spikes elsewhere (such as CPU usage). Destinations could be lagging on ingest and cause [backpressure](https://vector.dev/docs/about/under-the-hood/architecture/buffering-model/#backpressure-and-the-need-to-buffer) in the piplines.

definition.title: Bytes sent to destinations by pipeline

definition.content: Events in and events out **per pipeline**; use dashboard template variables to isolate this to a single pipeline by `pipeline_id` to get a clear cut understanding if a single pipeline is significantly sending or reducing events more than expected.

definition.title: Received minus sent events (diff) for source

definition.content: Indicates the difference between `@timestamp` and the time in which the source received the event.  Helpful when compared  to event spikes.

A ratio from 0 to 1 of the load on a component. A value of 0 would indicate a completely idle component that is simply waiting for input. A value of 1 would indicate a that is never idle. Components pegged at 1 should be reviewed as they likely are creating back pressure which could cause events to be dropped.

_Do note: sources dont have a utilization metric_

Success/Error Requests to destinations. High error rates my indicate some issue at the destination (e.g. elasticsearch rejecting submissions from OP) or possibly rejected events due to rules at the destination (e.g. events with timestamps that are beyond are certain time period)

definition.title: Intentionally discarded events (filtering, quotas, sampling, etc)

definition.content: Unintentionally discarded events. This is generally due to [backpressure](https://vector.dev/docs/about/under-the-hood/architecture/buffering-model/#backpressure-and-the-need-to-buffer) from destinations, which means the destination cannot keep up with the number of events being sent to it. Consider scaling your destination intake/workers to accommodate the load.

Error logs from OP Workers. For containerized OPW `pipelineid` is a tag on the log, for it to show up below, you will need to create a facet on these logs for the tag `pipelineid` first, then you will be able to use the pipeline_id template variable to filter to a specific pipeline. For non-containerized environments, the log attribute `op_worker.pipeline_id` needs to be made a facet. One or the other will be filled in below depending on deployment method.

Other (non-error) logs from OP Workers. For `@op_worker.pipelineId` to show up, you will need to create a facet on these logs for the attribute `op_worker.pipelineId` first, then you will be able to use the pipeline_id template variable to filter to a specific pipeline.

query.query_string: source:(observability-pipelines-worker OR op_worker) (pipelineid:$pipeline_id.value OR @op_worker.pipeline_id:$pipeline_id.value) NOT status:error $host

definition.content: This metric can show you if there are any significant spikes in data sent or if a pipeline is reducing events more than expected. Note: You may see spikes throughout the day which can be normal as we have seen in other pipelines.

definition.title: Unintentionally discarded events by pipeline_id and component

definition.content: Compare this data to the spikes in events to better if you need to scale up your destination workers/intake. This is generally due to [backpressure](https://vector.dev/docs/about/under-the-hood/architecture/buffering-model/#backpressure-and-the-need-to-buffer) from destinations and can indicate you need to scale your destination workers to accomodate the load.

definition.title: Received minus sent events (diff) for source
